bookCover.coverDescription:
Welcome to Compass, this is all generating awareness of the amazing range of technologies that are available to all students in DCU. The technologies range from tools within your:

  • DCU Goggle student account

  • DCU Microsoft account

  • A tool called Sensus Access

  • and services that impart technology skills to you.

Compass is all about supporting you to navigate these technologies and services so you can settle into your student journey. We'll give you tips about how these DCU technologies can help with:

  • different ways to use technology for reading

  • choices about how you can write an essay with technology

  • Ways to use technology to stay organised.

  • Signposting you to technology-linked services so you can get help and technology skills.

params.text:
Apple Computers

In some colleges, some learners may have access to Apple Mac Computers. These also have an abundance of inclusive technology.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

This guide was adapted with permission from Compass, created by Trevor Boland and DCU.

These inclusive technologies range from:

  • Reading (reading text aloud so you can hear and read it)
  • Dictation tools (type with your voice) and many more.

To see your options about these just go to 'System Preferences'

Then go to 'Accessibility'.

params.text:

These are just a few. To explore all your Mac possibilities, this YouTube Channel can help you.

params.text:
Have your Mac speak text

If you have trouble reading text on your screen, you can have your Mac speak text.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Listen to spoken text

  1. On your Mac, choose Apple menu 

     > System Settings, then click Accessibility in the sidebar. (You may need to scroll down.)

  2. Click Spoken Content on the right.

  3. Turn on “Speak selection”.

  4. On your Mac, press the specified keyboard shortcut (the default key combination is Option-Esc).

    If text is selected when you press the keyboard shortcut, the selected text is spoken. Otherwise, available text items in the current window are spoken; for example, if Mail is the current window, an email message is read.

    If you set the option to automatically show the controller, it appears onscreen when your Mac starts speaking. Use the controller to change the speaking rate, move forwards or backwards one sentence in the text, pause and resume speaking, or stop speaking.

    Note: If no text items are available, a beep sound plays.

  5. To stop the speaking, press the keyboard shortcut again.

params.title: text read out loud
params.alt: the options that appear in the read aloud - you can quicken, slow down and stop the reading.

params.text:
The Controller

The controller is especially useful when your Mac is reading long pieces of text.

The tortoise image slows down the reading and the hare speeds up the text.

You can use the controller to pause, resume or stop the speaking, change the speaking rate, and skip ahead or back in the text.

metadata.title: Reading out text on your Mac

params.text:
Typing with your Voice on a Mac

You can generate text from your voice easily on a Mac laptop or Desktop. When you switch this feature, you can speak out your written notes and convert them into a document. If you think your typing speed is slower than expected then maybe dictation would be a new option.

Most useful for: Get the first version of your hand written assignment typed up fast using this dictation tool. Then you can start to edit and proofread your assignment.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Turning on Dictation on a Mac Computer

  1. On your Mac, choose Apple menu 

     > System Settings, then click Keyboard  in the sidebar. (You may need to scroll down.)

  2. Go to Dictation on the right, then turn it on. If a prompt appears, click Enable.

Tip: You may need to insert a microphone to use dictation.

params.title: dictation setting on a mac
params.alt: how to activate your dictation in a mac. Go to the accessibility settings.

params.text:
Setting up and Trying Dictation on a Mac

  1. In an app on your Mac, place the insertion point where you want the dictated text to appear.

  1. Press the dictation keyboard shortcut or choose Edit > Start Dictation.

  1. When the feedback window shows a microphone icon with a fluctuating loudness indicator, or you hear the tone that signals your Mac is ready for keyboard dictation, dictate your text.

  1. Note: For best results, speak for no more than 40 seconds at a time.

  1. To insert a punctuation mark or perform simple formatting tasks, do any of the following:

  1. Say the name of the punctuation mark, such as “exclamation mark”.

  1. Say “new line” (equivalent to pressing the Return key once) or “new paragraph” (equivalent to pressing the Return key twice). After you say “new line”, the dictated text appears when you’ve finished dictating.

  1. For a list of the commands, you can use while dictating, see Commands for dictating text.
